result.execSummary:
The defendant Joshua T Ritz was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Fine to be paid at a rate of $43.33 for 12 months (w/payment plan fee of $15.00 for a total of $520.00) commencing 7/01/2015 and thereafter. Alternate 11 days jail.

Court finds that if the Defendant successfully completes probation and has no new criminal law violations, Court will find that it is in the Defendant's interest to have this expunged and society will not be harmed and grant expunction.

No contact with Nicholas or Taylor G.

with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Joshua T Ritz in court with attorney Nicole Williams-Buttery.  Bryan C. Bayer appeared for the State of Wisconsin.   Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 2.  Court finds defendant guilty. Ct. 1 dismissed and read-in. 

Court orders the following: 
Ct. 2:
- Fine totaling $505.00 plus the $15.00 payment plan fee for a total of $520.00. Defendant to make payments in the amount of $43.33 for the next 12 months beginning 07/01/2015 and thereafter; alternate 11 days jail
- Defendant to perform 40 hours of community within one year
- No contact with Nicholas or Taylor G. 

- Expunction addressed      
  State addresses expunction
  Court orders that if the defendant successfully makes all his payments in the next year and has no new law violations court finds society would not be harmed and it is in the 
  defendant's interest to grant expunction.
